title: Britons Back Stripping Andrew’s Title As Public Pressure Builds for Formal Epstein Inquiry | 10 News
description: New polling shows the vast majority of Britons support the stripping of Andrew Mountbatten Windsor's royal title, though many think King Charles should have acted earlier.   It comes as Virginia Giuffre's brother calls for a formal investigation in the former Prince's association with paedophile Jeffrey Epstein. title: Dozens Killed And Power Lines Down As Jamaica Begins Recovery From Hurricane Melissa | 10 News
description: The death toll from Hurricane Melissa has soared with almost 50 people killed in the deadliest storm to ever hit Jamaica.  The focus is now shifting to recovery, with aid, food and water desperately needed, as hundreds of thousands struggle without power. title: Two Arrested After Mass Stabbing On Train In England | 10 News
description: Two suspects have been arrested by UK police following a mass stabbing on a train in England overnight.  Emergency vehicles were called to Huntingdon train station near Cambridge on Saturday night after ten people were stabbed on board a train. The two men were arrested shortly afterward at a nearby station.  In a statement issued early on Sunday, British Transport Police said the incident had been declared a “major incident.”  Cambridgeshire Police reported that, “armed officers attended, and the train was stopped at Huntingdon, where two men were arrested.”  British Prime Minister Keir Starmer responded on social media, saying, “the appalling incident on a train near Huntingdon is deeply concerning. My thoughts are with those affected, and my thanks go to the emergency services for their response.”  The motive behind the stabbing remains unknown, and the incident is still under investigation. title: Teens Arrested Following Clash With D.C. Police On Halloween | 10 News
description: At least five teenagers were arrested after a violent clash with D.C.’s Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) on Friday night.  According to the Metropolitan Police Department, the arrests were made for “disorderly behaviour” on Halloween evening, with additional arrests carried out by Metro Transit Police.  Police reported that a crowd of about 700 people had gathered around 8pm, in a park area near downtown’s Navy Yard Metro station. The group began to block traffic, engage in multiple fights, and ignore orders to remain on the sidewalks.  MPD said five males between the ages of 14 and 18 were arrested on charges ranging from possession of a knife to failure to obey and resisting arrest. Metro Transit Police made additional arrests.  One officer was injured during the clash and treated by emergency services at the scene.  The crowd was finally dispersed around 11pm. title: Researchers Discover Potential New Dinosaur Species In 67 Million-Year-Old Fossils | 10 News+
description: Researchers believe they may have discovered a new dinosaur species called Nanotyrannus in 67-million-year-old fossils found in Montana in 2006. One of the skeletons was initially thought to be a young Tyrannosaurus rex, but a new research paper suggests otherwise. 10 News+ speaks to UNSW Paleontologist Michael Archer about this scientific development. title: Four Nations Conduct Military Drills in Disputed South China Sea | 10 News
description: The Philippines, United States, Australia, and New Zealand have conducted naval and air drills in the disputed South China Sea in recent days.  Videos released by the Armed Forces of the Philippines on Saturday show the exercises took place from Thursday to Friday, involving forces from all four nations.  This marks the 12th such joint military drill the Philippines has staged with allied countries since last year, aimed at protecting its sovereign rights in the contested waters.  Philippine military spokesperson Col. Xeres Trinidad said the exercises demonstrate “the enduring commitment of the four nations to strengthen maritime cooperation, enhance interoperability, and uphold peace and stability under a rules-based international order in the Indo-Pacific region.”  He did not provide any additional details, including the exact locations of the drills in the disputed waters. title: Path Forward Uncertain for Liberals as Nationals Withdraw Net Zero Support | 10 News
description: The Nationals have officially dumped their support for getting Australia to net zero emissions by 2050.  They unanimously came to the decision in a special party room meeting today which former leader Barnaby Joyce didn't attend.  The Nats decision to abandon the policy isn't surprising, but it creates a problem for the Liberals. title: President Donald Trump Threatens Military Action In West Africa Over Escalating Violence | 10 News
description: In his latest proclamation on social media the US President has threatened to take military action inside West Africa.   Donald Trump has escalated his language towards the Nigerian Government, accusing it of failing to protect Christians from increasing violence.   If it doesn't move fast, he says - America could go in guns-blazing. title: Man and Woman in Custody over Louvre Heist as Police Probe Wider Network | 10 News
description: Two more people accused of involvement in the Louvre heist are in custody, as authorities continue to trace the movements of an organised network.  A man and woman have been charged, while three others with them when police made the arrest, have been let go. title: Australian Father’s Mission To Help Solve UK Knife Crime Crisis | 10 News+
description: As the UK reels from a mass stabbing on a public train, one Australian father is on a mission to help solve the nation's knife crime crisis.   Brett Beasley is right now on his way to London to sell Jack's Law, which was created after his son was stabbed to death in 2019.   The powers allow police to wand citizens for knives and Brett believes it will help save lives in the UK. title: Exploring Options As Victoria Crime Crises Rages On | 10 News+
description: Crime has soared to record levels in Victoria with violent home invasions, carjackings and stabbings among the growingly frequent offences.   The Premier insists her tougher bail laws, and a machete ban will reign in the lawlessness, however, others disagree. Sam Butler has been investigating.
